MergedSelections: I am flying from Luton to Dalaman (Turkey) next week with Monarch and am wondering whether or not to bother with online check-in. [We already have allocated seats, so as far as I can see the only extra thing that online check-in offers is that you don't have to have your boarding pass printed at the check-in desk. Things that are putting me off are: (1) I've noticed over the past couple of years that because now most people are checking in online, the queues for the online check-in desks are often actually longer than the queues for people who haven't checked in online (2) Last year we had a 12 hour flight delay - the original plane had a problem and the airline then split passengers into two groups and people who had NOT checked in online were flown out on a much earlier plane than those who had checked in online - goodness knows why.]

MergedSelections: [i fly with china airlines from Los angeles to taipei with connecting flight to jakarta almost 20 hours flight. it was a very dissapointed experience from my 20 years flying experience. i'm a travel addict, i will travel at least 2 times a year to all over the world, n i ve been used many airlines, from asian airlines, european, even from arabian airlines..but china airlines is the biggest dissapointment. their ground staff are mean..never smile, no cooperation at all..i've never seen someone in service business that never give a smile...even starbuck who sell a cup of coffee give a smile everytime they serve. i travel with two small childrens, i asked her nicely that, if possible can she gave me a four in a row seats so we can be seating together..she respond NO without looking or even try to look for the seats..so in the end i've to beg other passangers on the aircraft so we can be seated together and the stewardess do not bother to help me out with this. and after all my documents finished and i received my boarding passes , i said thank you to her but she didn't respond or look at me..just pretend to be busy. at the boarding gate they call for a traveller with a small children to be onboard before the rest, so like i usually do ,i came forward and show them my ticket and my children but alas they rejected me at the gate and said what they mean is children under 2 years old. what is wrong with this peoples, what is the differences between 2 years old and 4 years old children ? so that's it ! this will be my last flight with china airlines.. i call my travel agent and said to them not to offer me this airlines again, better offer me a twin otter plane from some village airlines than this so called four star airlines...they do not deserve it]

MergedSelections: [The reason of this email is to explain an unfortunate situation, me and other 10 passengers suffered at the Denpasar Airport on the 19 of December 2015. We arrived at the Denpasar airport, 19 of December 2015 with the flight VA65 from Sydney. Virgin. Now, we went to the transit Area in Denpasar and ask for Qatar Airways assistance. Nobody was there to do the checkin for transit passengers. We requested assitance to the airport personnel, but they did not help at all and told us that I we did not want to loose the connection flight, we had to do custom clearance, get our luggage and do the check in again at the Qatar desk. The personnel of the airport was disrespectful and with a total lack of customer service attitude. We had little time to decide and we finally made to the check in counter of qatar at the airport. When we did the check in, we were charged 200.000 rp which I think is completely wrong. 1) The airport tax was included in my ticket as the regulation changed on February 2015, Denpasar Airport tax was included , as I booked my flight during Sept 2015. 2) We were passenger in transit that did not get any help from Qatar or airport personnel and we wanted to take our flight. Passengers in transit should not pay the 200.000 rp. So, for the above stated, and because it was Qatar airways the carrier collecting the money, I am requesting the refund of it as I paid it twice. Another point to have in mind, right now I am at the Denpasar airport again, as a transit passenger, I arrived from Doha with Qatar airways and I am connecting to Sydey with Virgin. Virgin personnel was waiting for us on the transit counter of the airport of Denpasar, we did the check in and we did not pay for anything. So Virgin did his part on this situation, and Qatar did not.]
Selected: The reason of this email is to explain an unfortunate situation, me and other 10 passengers suffered at the Denpasar Airport on the 19 of December 2015. We arrived at the Denpasar airport, 19 of December 2015 with the flight VA65 from Sydney. Virgin. Now, we went to the transit Area in Denpasar and ask for Qatar Airways assistance. Nobody was there to do the checkin for transit passengers. We requested assitance to the airport personnel, but they did not help at all and told us that I we did not want to loose the connection flight, we had to do custom clearance, get our luggage and do the check in again at the Qatar desk. The personnel of the airport was disrespectful and with a total lack of customer service attitude. We had little time to decide and we finally made to the check in counter of qatar at the airport. When we did the check in, we were charged 200.000 rp which I think is completely wrong. 1) The airport tax was included in my ticket as the regulation changed on February 2015, Denpasar Airport tax was included , as I booked my flight during Sept 2015. 2) We were passenger in transit that did not get any help from Qatar or airport personnel and we wanted to take our flight. Passengers in transit should not pay the 200.000 rp. So, for the above stated, and because it was Qatar airways the carrier collecting the money, I am requesting the refund of it as I paid it twice. Another point to have in mind, right now I am at the Denpasar airport again, as a transit passenger, I arrived from Doha with Qatar airways and I am connecting to Sydey with Virgin. Virgin personnel was waiting for us on the transit counter of the airport of Denpasar, we did the check in and we did not pay for anything. So Virgin did his part on this situation, and Qatar did not.

MergedSelections: [I have been a Life Member of Qantas Club for years but generally, these days, choose other airlines. For all the smoke and mirrors, Qantas is very ho-hum , ergo, dull and boring. After a series of serious in-flight incidents, the proud kangaroo has had a bit of PR disaster. While Qantas has not had an accident/incident where people died, tarnished is the operative word for them. They are gradually whittling away any benefits at all. Recently I booked with their subsidiary, Jetstar, Sydney - Honolulu return with business options. Here, the add-ons they normally charge to go cattle are generally included. I have a cattle class Sydney-Brisbane return with them as well and that has add-on costs galore. My real beef is the dreadful Jetstar website and lack of connection with that of Daddy QANTAS. In spite of endless patience and a very fast Internet connection, the Jetstar site is woefully slow and has severe Alzheimer's! The site continues to insist that I have no booking for my international leg although I have a confirmed itinerary and a booking number: absolutely a denial that such a booking exists. A call to their customer service department took two days to get through! It kept ringing out or I got a number unreachable message. When I did connect, I was assured there was such a booking but not according to my profile. However, the domestic booking is there! Go figure! With well over 400,000 frequent flyer points, Qantas has a couple of reward options for flight redemptions but of course, taxes can be extreme so one might just as well buy a ticket anyway. To sum up, Qantas] is a dead duck and I avoid them generally. My loyalty is focused elsewhere!

MergedSelections: After returning from Mexico with Thomas Cook in the Premier Cabin it has to be stated that the Premier Cabin is NOT WORTH the money. [The benifits of the Premier Cabin are several: *Dedicated check in (no waiting). *Complimentry drinks. *More leg room. *First on (and off) at your destination. THATS it.... You are told you will get a choice of meals; (chicken OR beef is the choice). Your luggage has Priority Hold labels fitted: (they mean nothing). Extra film channels: (the whole plane got them). When returning to the UK (G/Gow) my baggage ends up at Manchester. The Premier Cabin has 49 seats @ £300 per return trp which equals £14700, A LOT OF EXTRA MONEY FOR THOMAS COOK.... Then when you try to get in touch with them to talk about your grievances, they dont want to know, as they have your money and dont seem to care about customer service.. After nearly 2 weeks I am still waiting a response to several emails to them. CONCLUSION: Go on holiday with ANY ONE BUT THOMAS COOK.......]

MergedSelections: I know Jetstar regularly get a slating for their delays and bad service, so thought it was only fair I shared the excellent experience we had with them recently. [We flew Christchurch NZL to Narita Airport, Tokyo via the Gold Coast Airport. The flights were on time going over, no issues with delays or connections. The flight was delayed an hour coming back, but apart from that we had no issues with onwards connections, lost bags etc. The planes were lovely and service great. The thing that impressed us most was regarding our request to have luggage on the way back. We had booked a while back when they had a 2:1 special (2 fly for price of 1). We booked our basic flights ex Chch. Over the next few weeks we got several emails changing details of our flight. For the most part these were tiny changes: change of terminal, flights changing times by 5-10 minutes (in our favour), however, one of the changes was canning the return flight to Chch and putting us on a flight to Auckland, then a domestic flight to Chch. We didn't have any choice but to accept this as our trip was on quite a tight timeframe. Later we decided that we wanted to have one person with 10kg baggage on the way back to allow for a few souvenirs we planned to get. When we went to do this online, we found that it would cost us $98 (which we were prepared to pay) plus $15 more because of the domestic flight we now had through the change to their scheduling. We decided to wait until the airport and ask them there to waive the $15 as it was not our choice to do that leg. The lady at the airport counter spent quite a bit of time going through our booking history, then she handed us our boarding passes and said no problem. I pulled out my cc to pay for the Narita-AKL baggage and she said there was no charge for that either. We had asked for one person to have 10kg and she loaded 15kg baggage on both our tickets for free. We thought that was pretty good and were happy with that! When we got onto the Gold Coast-Auckland leg of our return flight we discovered we had exit row seats and then when the food trolley came round, the hostess informed us we each had $10 voucher for food. This was our first time flying long haul with a LCC. Even without the freebies we got as compensation for the change of return flight, we found it a good experience and would happily fly Jetstar long haul again out of NZ/Australia.]
Unselected: I know Jetstar regularly get a slating for their delays and bad service, so thought it was only fair I shared the excellent experience we had with them recently.
Selected: We flew Christchurch NZL to Narita Airport, Tokyo via the Gold Coast Airport. The flights were on time going over, no issues with delays or connections. The flight was delayed an hour coming back, but apart from that we had no issues with onwards connections, lost bags etc. The planes were lovely and service great. The thing that impressed us most was regarding our request to have luggage on the way back. We had booked a while back when they had a 2:1 special (2 fly for price of 1). We booked our basic flights ex Chch. Over the next few weeks we got several emails changing details of our flight. For the most part these were tiny changes: change of terminal, flights changing times by 5-10 minutes (in our favour), however, one of the changes was canning the return flight to Chch and putting us on a flight to Auckland, then a domestic flight to Chch. We didn't have any choice but to accept this as our trip was on quite a tight timeframe. Later we decided that we wanted to have one person with 10kg baggage on the way back to allow for a few souvenirs we planned to get. When we went to do this online, we found that it would cost us $98 (which we were prepared to pay) plus $15 more because of the domestic flight we now had through the change to their scheduling. We decided to wait until the airport and ask them there to waive the $15 as it was not our choice to do that leg. The lady at the airport counter spent quite a bit of time going through our booking history, then she handed us our boarding passes and said no problem. I pulled out my cc to pay for the Narita-AKL baggage and she said there was no charge for that either. We had asked for one person to have 10kg and she loaded 15kg baggage on both our tickets for free. We thought that was pretty good and were happy with that! When we got onto the Gold Coast-Auckland leg of our return flight we discovered we had exit row seats and then when the food trolley came round, the hostess informed us we each had $10 voucher for food. This was our first time flying long haul with a LCC. Even without the freebies we got as compensation for the change of return flight, we found it a good experience and would happily fly Jetstar long haul again out of NZ/Australia.

MergedSelections: [I flew to Stockholm with Finnair 3 weeks ago; on arriving after 8pm I found my baggage damaged but no one around to report it to. On flying back to London a few days later I went to report the damage to a Finnair employee in Stockholm; I was told that she couldn't do anything & to report it in Helsinki where I would get my connecting flight back to London; speaking to the Finnair employee In Helsinki I was told as I didn't have my case with me as it had been automatically transferred to the connecting flight that she couldn't help me & to report the damage in London when I had my case; back in London I am then informed by the 3rd Finnair employee that I had been given the wrong information & that it should have been dealt with in Stockholm; I was then told to speak to the baggage people at Heathrow who gave me an information sheet to email the company who deals with Finnair's damaged luggage with the photos & luggage tag; I subsequently didn't hear from them so I called up to be told they couldn't help me & to call Finnair customer services. After speaking to the 4th Finnair employee I am told to fill in the feedback form; that was almost 2 weeks ago; I have not heard anything or been asked for anymore information. ]Any ideas on who to contact to speed up the process of getting my baggage repaired/making a claim? [I will be flying again soon so any help is most appreciated!]

MergedSelections: A Qantas Boeing 747 traveling from London "lost power from all four of its main generators 15 minutes away from Bangkok, and the pilot was forced to switch to battery back-up for the landing," The Sydney Morning Herald reports. The Australian newspaper says the Monday incident "is set to prompt a worldwide alert to Boeing 747 operators after the problem was traced to a cracked drip tray under the first-class galley." In a story from this morning, the Morning Herald says "water from the blocked drain collected in a drip tray under the floor. A crack in the drip tray caused the water to leak into electrical wiring. Each of the plane's four engines has its own generator, but the water shorted out the aircraft's power supply." David Cox, Qantas' executive general manager responsible for engineering, tells The Australian "it was just like tipping a glass of water into your stereo." Dr. Arvind Sinha, director of aerospace at RMIT University in Melbourne, explains to the Morning Herald that "the engines have their own independent power source and the steering is operated by a hydraulic pump system, but the critical issues are the navigation and communication systems that you need to find your way to a runway to land." Colin Adams of the Australian and International Pilot's Association says the Qantas crew and passengers were "lucky" that the plane was not far out over open water when the incident occurred, according to the London Daily Mail. "In that situation you have a minimum of 30 minutes before you lose power to the flight instruments," Adams tells the Morning Herald. "After that the only idea that you have of airspeed and where you are in relation to what's around you is what you can see out of the window. There is no written procedure for what happens in that situation -- it's the pilot and his wits. If you were a long way from an airfield at night it would be an extremely hazardous situation. If you were in cloud you would not know where the ground was and you could end up in an extremely dangerous situation." The 747-400 is now back in service for Qantas, according to The Associated Press. "As a precaution, Qantas has inspected its entire B747-400 fleet and all of these aircraft have been cleared to fly," Qantas executive John Borghetti tells The Telegraph of London.[ Posted at 09:09 AM/ET, Jan 10, 2008 in International carriers, USAToday]

MergedSelections: [I recently returned from 3 weeks in Europe after flying with BA a few times and just wanted to share my experiences I had with the airline. ---- from YVR to LHR: Departed on time, arrived at LHR 20 minutes early. I paid about $100 extra for an exit row seat (28J) and couldn't recommend this more. The seat is located in the first row in Economy, right behind Club World. After takeoff, they close the curtain and due to there being no toilets here, there's no one walking around to disturb you. My seat was right beside the door which kind of protrudes out. This was used as my leg rest for the entire duration of the flight. If you can't afford Premium Economy, this is a really great option. Dinner was a choice of pasta (with feta and tomatoes) or chicken (with rice and veggies). I had the pasta which was actually quite tasty - by no means a five star meal, but not bad for plane food. The chocolate dessert was delicious. After dinner service, lights went out and it was time to sleep. A word of warning - it's extremely cold by the exits. I had a blanket and jacket but I was still shivering throughout the entire flight. In hindsight, I'm not sure why I didn't ask for an extra blanket - I must have been delirious with sleep... Breakfast is served about an hour before landing. It consisted of a fruit muffin, yogurt, and a box of raisins (?!). Not very filling, but oh well. IFE was average - I only watched one movie before going to sleep. The new releases were nothing to get excited about, so it may be wise to bring your own entertainment. BA85 from LHR to YVR: My experience on this flight was similar to the above, except this time I had seat 29K. This is also an exit row seat but in the second row of economy with a missing seat in front which allows you to enter the aisle by walking in front (and not over your seat mates). It was a good seat but not as good as any of the exit row seats in row 28 which just feel more spacious. This flight departed a bit late and arrived 45 minutes late at YVR. I also flew from LHR to BCN (BA486), and AMS to LHR (BA435) on their smaller planes. Both plane interiors looked brand spanking new. I managed to score exit row seats on both these fights as well which was a nice bonus even though the flights were quite short in duration. There's no IFE but they do serve a small snack and free drinks on both flights. I don't know what the snacks were as I declined them on both flights. ]Overall, a very good experience with BA. They're definitely my airline of choice when flying to, from, and within Europe, especially if I can get an exit row seat on the international flights.[ Edited: 11:28 pm, July 13, 2015]
Unselected: Overall, a very good experience with BA. They're definitely my airline of choice when flying to, from, and within Europe, especially if I can get an exit row seat on the international flights.

MergedSelections: [I fly a lot for biz and pleasure and just got back from London to New York last week after connecting from Spain. I have never been on a more unpleasant flight. I was in economy class. A 7+ hour flight with a family of 4 behind me. The kids were an infant maybe 4 months old and a 2 year old. The kids alternated crying, screaming, howling and seat kicking the entire flight. Parents did nothing to stop this. Directly beside across the aisle were 2 parents with Junior lap baby that looked way to big to be a lap baby. Just before the lunch service Dad decided he was going to change Junior's very soiled diaper right there in the seat. From my vantage point, I could both see and smell everything that was going on. Absolutely vile. Needless to say, I was shocked. Just before landing, round # 2. The parents just rolled up the used diapers and placed them under the seats! The aircraft bathrooms had diaper changing tables too! A lack of class by these parents.] Wondering if anyone else has witnessed such rude behavior lately while flying? Would you have complained to the Crew?

MergedSelections: [Dear Air France and fellow passengers,] I write here today to explain to anyone considering flying with Air France to reconsider[. The service I have received by them in the last 24h has been absolutely appalling. After a cancelled flight I was made to wait for almost 4 hours to be attended, at which time any options for rebooking has already left or were full. Hence my morning meeting on 23/11 will be missed, and my prepaid car rental at MIA is lost. I reschedule meetings for 4pm on 23/11 assuming a 12:25 landing. After waking up at 5am I arrive at the airport to find that my 8:30am flight had become a 10:20am flight (no email or courtesy call from AF). So another meeting to reschedule last minute and perhaps lost business. Additionally the upgrade to premium economy I was promised.....no longer the case today! This is the absolute worst treatment by an airline I have ever received and I intent to pursue my rights as a passenger according to EC261/2004 or other applicable regulations to ensure my losses and expenses are reimbursed. Yours sincerely, Bob Vandedrink]

MergedSelections: I have recently switched to Clear Care, a hydrogen peroxide based contact lens solution, [due to my eye care professional's recommendation. In a few months, this will be my first time traveling with it (by air). ]I have been hearing stories of TSA officers confiscating such solution in carry on baggage and not being able to negotiate citing medical necessity as a reason, even when the bottle is in compliance with the 3-1-1 limitation. The reasoning is that hydrogen peroxide can potentially be used as an explosive. I am wondering what people's experiences are with this?[ I have always known that it is best to have enough of your contact lens care material in your carry on baggage in case your checked baggage gets delayed. However, I now use exclusively Clear Care, and if that does not make it through TSA, I will be left with nothing upon arrival if my checked baggage gets delayed. I am planning to travel to an Asian destination, where there is almost no guarantee that I will be able to find the product for sale. I wear the overnight ortho-K lenses, thus I do not own a pair of prescription glasses, nor do I have any need for them.]

MergedSelections: [After a few tense days of waiting for an outcome,] USAirways International Customer Service has come through with shining colors. [I accidently entered my last name on my mother's reservation to Italy and the mistake was not caught immediately. After reporting the problem via their website, I searched the internet to find all kinds of horrible results to similar situations including having to repurchase the ticket (without refund) at the current going rate. The current rate is now $500 more than it was a week ago! I would like to thank Shirley from International Reservations for her diligent persistence in helping me to correct a name error. Without her help, I would still be worrying whether TSA would allow my mother to fly with the ticket on which I incorrectly entered my last name instead of hers. Shirley was great and fixed the problem with no issue. She was polite during the entire transaction and gave me updates along the way so I would feel comfortable on hold. Thanks again for her help. Also, thank you to Dan from Internet Support for starting the correction process.]
Unselected: USAirways International Customer Service has come through with shining colors.
Selected: After a few tense days of waiting for an outcome,I accidently entered my last name on my mother's reservation to Italy and the mistake was not caught immediately. After reporting the problem via their website, I searched the internet to find all kinds of horrible results to similar situations including having to repurchase the ticket (without refund) at the current going rate. The current rate is now $500 more than it was a week ago! I would like to thank Shirley from International Reservations for her diligent persistence in helping me to correct a name error. Without her help, I would still be worrying whether TSA would allow my mother to fly with the ticket on which I incorrectly entered my last name instead of hers. Shirley was great and fixed the problem with no issue. She was polite during the entire transaction and gave me updates along the way so I would feel comfortable on hold. Thanks again for her help. Also, thank you to Dan from Internet Support for starting the correction process.

MergedSelections: Think wait-times at U.S. airports are maddening? If so, then consider this dramatically written story from the Hindustan Times of New Delhi, where international passengers are being advised to arrive four hours before their flights. The paper says "passengers trying to board flights at (New Delhi's) Indira Gandhi International Airport have fainted or have had epileptic fits due to the claustrophobic conditions prompted by construction work that has led to the closure of large chunks of areas, airlines operating from the airport have said. The airport — in the midst of a massive facelift — has shrunk considerably, leading to serpentine queues that regularly delay flights. People have missed their flights as they spend hours first battling a gut-crushing rush at the airport's entrance and then the immigration counters during the peak travel season." Construction is scheduled to end in April.

The airport — in the midst of a massive facelift — has shrunk considerably, leading to serpentine queues that regularly delay flights. People have missed their flights as they spend hours first battling a gut-crushing rush at the airport's entrance and then the immigration counters during the peak travel season." Construction is scheduled to end in April.

MergedSelections: Always one to reduce costs, Ryanair are implementing cost saving initiatives. [With the rising cost of fuel the airline has found ways of reducing the fuel bill by reducing the weight it carries on its flights. They will be shrinking the size of its in-flight magazines from A4 to A5 size, carrying less ice on flights and believe it or not, "encouraging" staff to watch their weight - with the motivation of appearing in the annual Ryanair calendar! But Ryanair are only following in the foot steps of other airlines ... In the 1980's, American Airlines claimed that they saved $40,000 by taking out one olive from every salad in first class and more recently, Japanese airline All Nippon Airways started asking passengers to go to the toilet before boarding in a bid to reduce carbon emissions! ]Without fuel you cannot fly, but I think that's taking things a step too far !
Unselected: Always one to reduce costs, Ryanair are implementing cost saving initiatives. Without fuel you cannot fly, but I think that's taking things a step too far !

They will be shrinking the size of its in-flight magazines from A4 to A5 size, carrying less ice on flights and believe it or not, "encouraging" staff to watch their weight - with the motivation of appearing in the annual Ryanair calendar! But Ryanair are only following in the foot steps of other airlines ... In the 1980's, American Airlines claimed that they saved $40,000 by taking out one olive from every salad in first class and more recently, Japanese airline All Nippon Airways started asking passengers to go to the toilet before boarding in a bid to reduce carbon emissions!

MergedSelections: Over the years Qantas has moved out of many regional routes and replaced their Qantas flights with Jetstar. [I travel a lot to/from Sydney and use Jetstar 6+ times a month which of course always take off and land at T2 in Sydney. So, Qantas in its wisdom (or a sign of the economic times) has closed the Qantas Club Lounge at T2. A lot of us pay $450+ per year for a Qantas Club membership - if you cant fly Qantas (because they now fly Jetstar) the lounge in T2 was well worth it. Qantas say "oh, just use the lounge in T3" - well, easier said than done - you have to go through security at T3 to get to the Qantas lounge (ever done that at 7am in the morning), then leave T3 and go through security again at T2. Qantas say they haven't had very many complaints on this closure (have you ever tried to navigate the Qantas web site to find a complaint form?). I've read them several times. Dear Delta, please just remove the program all together if you don't want to honor it! No one is making you have this program! Don't waste our time!  Now that I'm researching it, I've yet to come across anyone who has been approved. I'll definitely be looking at other options next time I fly, not because of the lack of a price match, but because of the awful customer service I have received. Imagine if something really went wrong and you needed something!

MergedSelections: [Hi, As information for any US passport holder or future applicant. New passport fees will become effective from 13 July 2010 onward. This is for all applications lodged *on or after* this date. Remember if you use a passport acceptance office (like a US post office) or one of the regional Department of State Passport Offices, it's the date on which you actually file or submit your application that will determine the fee matrix. If you are eligible to, and use regular US Mail for submission, it's the post mark date that will govern. Note that the one of the biggest increases (expressed as percentage) is in the additional page insert fee, which goes from *free* to $82 per insert added. Here's the entire new fee matrix from the DoS' Passport Services page: travel.state.gov/passport/fees/fees_5079.html If your passport is going to expire soon, will have less than 6 months validity, or you need to add extra pages, this would be an *excellent* time to do so, before the new fee matrix becomes applicable. Travel Safe,]
Selected: Hi, As information for any US passport holder or future applicant. New passport fees will become effective from 13 July 2010 onward. MergedSelections: [my wife and I were returning from Manchester, UK to D.C., then on to Louisville, KY. a *HUGE* storm brought down powerlines on the tracks of the UK train that was to get us to Manchester airport. We had to wind up taking a taxi, but half way there it was obvious that we would no make our flight. From the cab, I cell-phoned the only number I had - a toll-free US number. AUnited agent finally came on the line and I expalined the situ to her. Long time on hold.... Then she came back. Not only did the lady on the phone get us rescheduled on the same two flights on the following day, but there was *NO* "change fee" charged to us for making the changes! I was astounded! It reminded me of the "old days" when it was a snap to make last-minute flight changes without penalties. Anyway, ]I want to thank United for getting us back safe & sound and let them know that they will be at the top of our list for carriers when we book our next overseas flights!
Unselected: I want to thank United for getting us back safe & sound and let them know that they will be at the top of our list for carriers when we book our next overseas flights!
Selected: my wife and I were returning from Manchester, UK to D.C., then on to Louisville, KY. a *HUGE* storm brought down powerlines on the tracks of the UK train that was to get us to Manchester airport. We had to wind up taking a taxi, but half way there it was obvious that we would no make our flight. From the cab, I cell-phoned the only number I had - a toll-free US number. AUnited agent finally came on the line and I expalined the situ to her. Long time on hold.... Then she came back. Not only did the lady on the phone get us rescheduled on the same two flights on the following day, but there was *NO* "change fee" charged to us for making the changes! I was astounded! It reminded me of the "old days" when it was a snap to make last-minute flight changes without penalties. Anyway,

MergedSelections: [Flying yesterday from Istanbul to Stockholm (TK 1795), I tried to check in on-line the day before. I was surprised that ]on-line check in failed because "you have been allocated an exit row seat". [I had not requested an exit row seat, nor made any seat request, expecting to do that at check-in. The airline had no way of knowing my state of health and physical ability, apart from having flown TK three times previously in the last month, none of these flights being in an exit row. At Ataturk, I mentioned this to a supervisor, and she just handed me the boarding pass and shrugged her shoulders when I asked for an explanation. Incidentally at on-line check in I wasn't able to change the seat allocation, and by the time I got to Ataturk the plane was full, so it was lucky I was able-bodied, and that my able-bodiedness was not required.] Can anyone explain this "method" of seat allocation ?
Unselected: on-line check in failed because "you have been allocated an exit row seat".  Can anyone explain this "method" of seat allocation ?
Selected: Flying yesterday from Istanbul to Stockholm (TK 1795), I tried to check in on-line the day before. I was surprised that I had not requested an exit row seat, nor made any seat request, expecting to do that at check-in. The airline had no way of knowing my state of health and physical ability, apart from having flown TK three times previously in the last month, none of these flights being in an exit row. At Ataturk, I mentioned this to a supervisor, and she just handed me the boarding pass and shrugged her shoulders when I asked for an explanation. Incidentally at on-line check in I wasn't able to change the seat allocation, and by the time I got to Ataturk the plane was full, so it was lucky I was able-bodied, and that my able-bodiedness was not required.

MergedSelections: [I paid $80.00 for flight insurance from Access America. I had flown to Hollywood, FL from NYC to be with my husband for Christmas while he visited his elderly father in the hospital. I planned to fly back after a week. Then my father-in-law died two days after Christmas. Now Access America is refusing my claim. This is outrageous. Access America refused my claim because my father-in-law's death was "either known to you or likely to happen." I had no idea he was going to die when he did or I wouldn't have made the flight reservations in the first place. My husband and I are self-employed so one of us had to get back to the business. We couldn't both stay there for the days, weeks or months he might have lasted. When he passed away it became more important for me to stay with my husband. Now Access America is telling me my only recourse is arbitration, which involves a fee and court appearance.] Access America is in the business of taking people's money. [----- ---------- NYC, NY]

MergedSelections: Yesterday I flew home from Jeddah via Doha on Qater Airways.[ On boarding the flight from Doha to Manchester it was quite chaotic in the forward economy cabin of the Airbus A330. Numerous families had unilaterally decided to seat themselves together regardless of their seat assignments. The poor FA spent 15 mins trying to get people into their correct seats. I reserved my usual aisle seat, but I had now been moved into a central aisle seat rather than my usual window aisle seat. I would hazard a guess this occurred to try and keep a family on the same row if possible, no big deal to be honest. However in my row was a mother and 2 children. The father of the family demanded rather than ask that I change seats with him, now if he'd been seated in business then fair enough, even accounting for his rather rude attitude. However he was seated in a centre seat behind me, I told him sorry but I dislike to being trapped in. He then became extremely rude, at which point I reported him to the FA. The FA had a word with him and he went off in Huff to his seat. Several hours later his young son looked at me and said " your the nasty bl@@dy man who wouldn't move" I guess that comment says it all really, clearly such language shouldn't come from a 3 yr old child. I have moved before to try and assist a family, as long as it's a similar seat close by then that's fine. This rather rude incident will definitely give me pause for thought in future. I think it was the overriding rude sense of entitlement that annoyed me. Regards Rick]
Unselected: Yesterday I flew home from Jeddah via Doha on Qater Airways.
Selected: On boarding the flight from Doha to Manchester it was quite chaotic in the forward economy cabin of the Airbus A330. Numerous families had unilaterally decided to seat themselves together regardless of their seat assignments. The poor FA spent 15 mins trying to get people into their correct seats. I reserved my usual aisle seat, but I had now been moved into a central aisle seat rather than my usual window aisle seat. I would hazard a guess this occurred to try and keep a family on the same row if possible, no big deal to be honest. However in my row was a mother and 2 children. The father of the family demanded rather than ask that I change seats with him, now if he'd been seated in business then fair enough, even accounting for his rather rude attitude. However he was seated in a centre seat behind me, I told him sorry but I dislike to being trapped in. He then became extremely rude, at which point I reported him to the FA. The FA had a word with him and he went off in Huff to his seat. Several hours later his young son looked at me and said " your the nasty bl@@dy man who wouldn't move" I guess that comment says it all really, clearly such language shouldn't come from a 3 yr old child. I have moved before to try and assist a family, as long as it's a similar seat close by then that's fine. This rather rude incident will definitely give me pause for thought in future. I think it was the overriding rude sense of entitlement that annoyed me. Regards Rick

MergedSelections: [Recently had a brilliant short visit to Saigon. Absolutely loved Vietnam. However, on arrival home, locks on 2 pieces of luggage were (quite obviously) intentionally broken. Plus everything inside was moved around. There were 6 bags altogether but only 2 were broken into. I figured it probably happened at Saigon as we checked in 2 hrs earlier but when we got home, all the luggage was out immediately. We haven't yet noticed anything missing. I made a mistake of leaving few one dollar notes in there which definitely was a temptation. Dont put anything that can be 'tempting' in your check in luggage even if it doesnt cost much eg. costume jewellery/ accesories. ]Locks dont always keep your stuff safe.
Unselected: Locks dont always keep your stuff safe.
Selected: Recently had a brilliant short visit to Saigon. Absolutely loved Vietnam. However, on arrival home, locks on 2 pieces of luggage were (quite obviously) intentionally broken. Plus everything inside was moved around. There were 6 bags altogether but only 2 were broken into. I figured it probably happened at Saigon as we checked in 2 hrs earlier but when we got home, all the luggage was out immediately. We haven't yet noticed anything missing. I made a mistake of leaving few one dollar notes in there which definitely was a temptation. Dont put anything that can be 'tempting' in your check in luggage even if it doesnt cost much eg. costume jewellery/ accesories.

MergedSelections: [We wanted to change our original round trip from Phoenix to Columbus to a three legged trip, from Phoenix to Columbus, then Columbus to Milwaukee to Rhinelander, then Rhinelander to Milwaukee to Phoenix. Our original reservations were on Southwest. Had to call customer service to change because our departure city was different, but the agent was able to help me, and we ended up with a $100 credit. Frontier is the only airline to fly nonstop from Columbus to Milwaukee, plus the only airline to fly out of Rhinelander. The first time I checked the fare was $175. Due to circumstances beyond my control, could not book it then. Last Thursday, ready to book, fare was $458! After I recovered from my heart attack, I explored other options and booked the lowest fare I could find, Delta thru Memphis, then Frontier to Rhinelander. (Knowing we'd have to pay a change fee if we had to change the Delta flights) Today I get an email from Frontier that the Rhinelander flight times have changed, and wouldn't you know, our flight from Memphis gets in at 4:20 and the flight to Rhinelander now leaves at 4:15! So now we have to stay overnight in Milwaukee!! Oh, and the Frontier agent's first response was to cancel our flights! He didn't care how we got to Land O'Lakes! Off the check the cost of renting a car for 10 days - and ]anyone know a decent cheap hotel with a shuttle at MKE?
Unselected: anyone know a decent cheap hotel with a shuttle at MKE?

MergedSelections: We returned Saturday evening from London via British Airway. Part of our bucket list (things we want to experience before we "kick the bucket") was to fly British Airways First Class and/or Business Class. [I hope anyone with a love of travel and have traveled for many years squeezed into "the back", can have this experience!. All you need to do is save up those Frequent Flyer miles for years and years of loyally flying the Star Alliance airlines in the narrow, crowded seats and keeping a sense of humor knowing you are doing your favorite thing, traveling to far away countries. We will probably never again be able to afford to travel this way, certainly not enough time to collect miles nor save enough money....BUT , the memory of this experience on British Airways will last until the end of our days. ]In past years when I traveled domestically first class for business with my employer paying the fare , it was NOTHING like this. Airlines, and service have come a long way, Never could I imagine this experience.[ I remember boarding in the back, under the tail, and walking up the aisle, and using a pillow for a tray....Ahhh, and now sleeping pods, pajamas, slippers, 5 star meals, top shelf spirits and the most polite incredible flight attendants, obviously the creme de la creme.. Now, we two "mature" people celebrating our 50th anniversary, know what goes on behind the curtain!.] I hope all you lovers of travel can share the experience one day.
Unselected: We returned Saturday evening from London via British Airway. Part of our bucket list (things we want to experience before we "kick the bucket") was to fly British Airways First Class and/or Business Class. In past years when I traveled domestically first class for business with my employer paying the fare , it was NOTHING like this. Airlines, and service have come a long way, Never could I imagine this experience. I hope all you lovers of travel can share the experience one day.
Selected: I hope anyone with a love of travel and have traveled for many years squeezed into "the back", can have this experience!. All you need to do is save up those Frequent Flyer miles for years and years of loyally flying the Star Alliance airlines in the narrow, crowded seats and keeping a sense of humor knowing you are doing your favorite thing, traveling to far away countries. We will probably never again be able to afford to travel this way, certainly not enough time to collect miles nor save enough money....BUT , the memory of this experience on British Airways will last until the end of our days.  I remember boarding in the back, under the tail, and walking up the aisle, and using a pillow for a tray....Ahhh, and now sleeping pods, pajamas, slippers, 5 star meals, top shelf spirits and the most polite incredible flight attendants, obviously the creme de la creme.. Now, we two "mature" people celebrating our 50th anniversary, know what goes on behind the curtain!.

MergedSelections: [Date: Sun, 27 Feb 2011 12:51:29 -0600 13 hours late , the only positive was the polite and professional Frontier counter ticket attendant hit by a wave of frustrated , tired united passengers at 4am at the Denver terminal.. Once in Minneapolis we were told by Delta that we did not have reservations to fly to Fargo , even though the ticket we received did show a flight , we were then told to see a United ticket agent , and that was in a different terminal . Well off i went , unfortunately the first agent i found was on the phone , he proceeded to tell me , by putting his hand on receiver that he will be on the phone for awhile , i then grabbed my TICKETS and proceeded to the next gate , still not knowing whether we had a flight . The next terminal had an agent dealing with a client , 2 other people were standing just behind the gate having an animated conversation , after 10 mins 1 left and went back to original United gate ..The agent was off the phone , looked at my tickets , reprinted them and said YOU DO have reservations for that flight , go see delta . Off i went to delta again , different terminal again , I was again told by Delta we did not have reservations and I need to go back to United !!!!!!!!!!! At this point I was probably I step away from loosing it , the agent then offered me the United PHONE NUMBER !! ..... After some enormous restraint I insisted she call !! She told me to have a seat , finally I i overheard her mention they had marked an HL or something on the ticket or reservation !!! I have no idea what that meant , shortly after she called us up and asked for our identification !!! we received or tickets and proceeded to our gate ... c 9 then c 10 and then f 1 .... We were a party of 4 , 2 of witch are mid 70 senior citizens , in the 13 hours it took , every time we had to bounce from terminal to terminal they went with us , this was very stress full on them , we had originally boarded united in vegas Friday flight 6659 friday ..I have not checked my credit card statement but we had 2 rooms booked for late check in 130 am saturday morning in Fargo ,ND , as Fargo was not our final destination , so i may find i have been charged for these rooms as well . In Denver the night shift gave us hotel voucher , not used and told use to go to www.unitedapprecition.com for additional information] .WE WERE OFFERED 50.00 Travel Voucher !!!!!!! signed SLEEPLESS with UNITED

MergedSelections: [Just my luck. It's my Daughter's 18th today. Had a meal planned to celebrate for ages now and my flight booked months ago. ]Got up at 0530 this morning to get ready to go to the airport and had a text from Easyjet to tell me the flight was concelled. [Blooming heck I said, or words t that effect, what am I going to do now? To top it off I forgot that they sent me a mail ages ago changing the flight to 1020 so not only have they cancelled I got up two hours early:-((((( Not blaming EZY for the horrendous snow but I tried to call customer services at 0600 and was on the phone for 30 mins before giving up. I wanted to see if I could change the flight to go to MAN then catch a train which you can't seem to do online, only reschedule the flight or get a refund. Anyway I have managed to get on KLM (€220 !) but not until 2100 tonight. There was a flight at 1500 but after procrastinating about what to do and hanging on the phone to Easyjet that quickly filled up as KLM also cancelled their morning flights to and from EDI. ]Moral of this story is don't hang about in these situations. Carpe diem and grab the next available flight before some other bugg3r does. [Anyway will miss the meal but these things happen. Never had a flight cancelled before due to weather but it would have to be today of all days.At least EZY managed to let me know by text and e-mail BEFORE I left for Schiphol. By the way flgihts to Glasgow for the next few days were over €500 on KLM. I only wanted a seat not an executive jet!! Moan over ;-)]

MergedSelections: [Dear Readers I recently (June and July2010) travelled to Europe from Australia with my wife and 3 children aged 16,11 and 9. We visited France, Greece and England. I booked and paid for 3 flights with Easy Jet prior to our departure. The first two flights were uneventful. However our last flight from Athens to London ended up blowing my holiday budget out of the water. We were booked on an Olympic Air flight out of Paros in the Greek Islands a flight that is 20 minutes in length and was scheduled to depart at 16.05pm. Our Easy Jet Connection was due to depart at 19.00 and check in closed at 18.20. Due to the late incoming plane to Paros we did not arrive in at Athens airport until 17.55pm and we were promptly transferred to the terminal by an awaiting bus and were in the terminal at 18.00. I advised my wife and children to go and retrieve the bags and I raced up to the Easy Jet counter to commence check in. By the time I got to the counter it was 18.18pm on my watch and on the clocks in the terminal but there were no Easy Jet staff at the check in at all. The next day there was an Air Traffic Controllers strike that had been scheduled and we had non-refundable accommodation and other paid activities in London. I went looking for the Easy Jet representative in the Terminal who advised that as it was at that stage, 18.21pm by her watch the flight had closed, there were no staff available and there was nothing she could do other than advise us that due to industrial action and bookings we would not be likely to get paid seats with Easy Jet for 3 days. Faced with this I looked for flights departing to London that night and found a British Airways flight due to depart at 19.10. I was advised by a BA representative that she may be able to get 5 seats but would not know until 18.40. She managed to get 5 economy seats for which I was charged in excess of EURO2500 or Australian $3557.00. I spoke to BA the next day in London and a staff member told me that I was charged adult fares for the two children under 12 and that I should be entitled to a 25% refund. The battle to do this is still going on with the BA refunds section and the initial response that I received when the matter was referred to BA customer relations was that BA only have 2 classes of economy seats adult and infant ie 2 and under. There website would suggest otherwise. I have written to Easy Jet and am awaiting a response and will detail it in this forum when it is to hand. I think the moral of this story is that allow the widest possible berth between connection if travelling on a discount carrier. Do not accept the check in closure time will be adhered to by staff of a budget carrier and make sure that you have travel insurance that covers the scenario of a missed connection, as many policies in this regard will only give you a limited amount in very limited circumstances. I will keep you all posted. ------- Sydney]
Selected: Dear Readers I recently (June and July2010) travelled to Europe from Australia with my wife and 3 children aged 16,11 and 9. We visited France, Greece and England. I booked and paid for 3 flights with Easy Jet prior to our departure. The first two flights were uneventful. However our last flight from Athens to London ended up blowing my holiday budget out of the water. We were booked on an Olympic Air flight out of Paros in the Greek Islands a flight that is 20 minutes in length and was scheduled to depart at 16.05pm. Our Easy Jet Connection was due to depart at 19.00 and check in closed at 18.20. Due to the late incoming plane to Paros we did not arrive in at Athens airport until 17.55pm and we were promptly transferred to the terminal by an awaiting bus and were in the terminal at 18.00. I advised my wife and children to go and retrieve the bags and I raced up to the Easy Jet counter to commence check in. By the time I got to the counter it was 18.18pm on my watch and on the clocks in the terminal but there were no Easy Jet staff at the check in at all. The next day there was an Air Traffic Controllers strike that had been scheduled and we had non-refundable accommodation and other paid activities in London. I went looking for the Easy Jet representative in the Terminal who advised that as it was at that stage, 18.21pm by her watch the flight had closed, there were no staff available and there was nothing she could do other than advise us that due to industrial action and bookings we would not be likely to get paid seats with Easy Jet for 3 days. Faced with this I looked for flights departing to London that night and found a British Airways flight due to depart at 19.10. I was advised by a BA representative that she may be able to get 5 seats but would not know until 18.40. She managed to get 5 economy seats for which I was charged in excess of EURO2500 or Australian $3557.00. I spoke to BA the next day in London and a staff member told me that I was charged adult fares for the two children under 12 and that I should be entitled to a 25% refund. The battle to do this is still going on with the BA refunds section and the initial response that I received when the matter was referred to BA customer relations was that BA only have 2 classes of economy seats adult and infant ie 2 and under. There website would suggest otherwise. I have written to Easy Jet and am awaiting a response and will detail it in this forum when it is to hand. I think the moral of this story is that allow the widest possible berth between connection if travelling on a discount carrier. Do not accept the check in closure time will be adhered to by staff of a budget carrier and make sure that you have travel insurance that covers the scenario of a missed connection, as many policies in this regard will only give you a limited amount in very limited circumstances. I will keep you all posted. ------- Sydney

MergedSelections: [I just wanted to post this in case anyone else has flight anxiety. I get very nervous on flights, and at one time, broke into full blown tears becuase I thought the plane was going down in turbulence! I went to my doctor, and she just wrote me a script for Ativan. I wanted to try to kick this fear DRUG FREE. On my Ipod, ]I downloaded an App - Virgin Atlantic Fear of Flying. It was $4.99 and worth every penny. [It has videos of a captain talking about different sounds, movements, and things to expect. It has demos on how planes operate, land, take off, etc as well. It also has those relaxation tracks on it. (a guy speaking sllllooowly and telling you everything is going to be fiiiinnne.) I listened to it on my last flight the whole way, and the 2 weeks leading up to it. By no means do I love flying now, but I can tolerate it, and I'm not anxious and fearful. I encourage anyone with the same feelings that I did to check it out!]
Unselected: I downloaded an App - Virgin Atlantic Fear of Flying. It was $4.99 and worth every penny.
Selected: I just wanted to post this in case anyone else has flight anxiety. I get very nervous on flights, and at one time, broke into full blown tears becuase I thought the plane was going down in turbulence! I went to my doctor, and she just wrote me a script for Ativan. I wanted to try to kick this fear DRUG FREE. On my Ipod, It has videos of a captain talking about different sounds, movements, and things to expect. It has demos on how planes operate, land, take off, etc as well. It also has those relaxation tracks on it. (a guy speaking sllllooowly and telling you everything is going to be fiiiinnne.) I listened to it on my last flight the whole way, and the 2 weeks leading up to it. By no means do I love flying now, but I can tolerate it, and I'm not anxious and fearful. I encourage anyone with the same feelings that I did to check it out!

MergedSelections: My husband and I went to Hawaii (July 2009) for our Honeymoon and were stranded on the Big Island by this airline. [They stopped flying out of Kona days before our flight. They did not contact us and when we got to the airport we found a phone at their counter and were told we were pretty much out of luck. They had not made alternate arrangements, nor could they help. We did not have the credit card we'd used for purchase and were told to call when we got home and they'd refund our money. We specifically asked if we needed to do anything else and were told all we needed was the credit card. Now that we're home they're saying we need to return the paper tickets that the other person was wrong. I find if ludicrous that they strand us and then try to shift responsibility to us for their mistake. We don't have the tickets, so we're supposed to talk to corporate. We've left messages 3 times now and no one is calling back. The only phone number on the website is to reservations and they will send a message, that goes unanswered. ]I checked Better Business Bureau and they have an F rating and a history of this type of problem and they don't respond to complaints from BBB.[ Avoid. Avoid. Avoid.]
Unselected: My husband and I went to Hawaii (July 2009) for our Honeymoon and were stranded on the Big Island by this airline. I checked Better Business Bureau and they have an F rating and a history of this type of problem and they don't respond to complaints from BBB.
Selected: They stopped flying out of Kona days before our flight. They did not contact us and when we got to the airport we found a phone at their counter and were told we were pretty much out of luck. They had not made alternate arrangements, nor could they help. We did not have the credit card we'd used for purchase and were told to call when we got home and they'd refund our money. We specifically asked if we needed to do anything else and were told all we needed was the credit card. Now that we're home they're saying we need to return the paper tickets that the other person was wrong. I find if ludicrous that they strand us and then try to shift responsibility to us for their mistake. We don't have the tickets, so we're supposed to talk to corporate. We've left messages 3 times now and no one is calling back. The only phone number on the website is to reservations and they will send a message, that goes unanswered.  Avoid. Avoid. Avoid.

MergedSelections: [British Airways has refused to reimburse us (wife and I) for expenses we incurred due to their cancellation of our flight. They offered $150 travel voucher each. Our costs are $470.44. We arrived at LHR at 10AM on May 24, 2013. BA advised that all flights were now canceled until 4PM. That meant our 3PM flight to CPH was canceled. We stood in line at BA Customer Service for ten hours, along with hundreds of others. Customer Service only opened 4 windows. As the hours crawled by - tempers flared. We got to the window at 8PM. No flights available this day, nor the next day - that would get us to CPH in time for the evening sailing of our cruise ship. We agreed to an 10AM standby for CPH, and a alternative code share routing that would get us close to the port where the ship would be on the second sailing day. We spent the night wandering Heathrow Airport, and retrieved our checked luggage. Not much sleep. Next morning - no luck at Standby. Rushed to the alternate plan - and flew up to Manchester UK. Then - rushed to another terminal to partner Lufthanza for a flight to Munich Germany. From there, Lufthanza toHamburg - where we arrived at midnight of May 25 - on a weekend night - without a hotel reservation. Taxied to a hotel (very lucky) and got a few hours sleep. May 26 - off to the train station: took train to Rostock, them S-bahn to Warnemunde. Hurray - that is where our cruise ship was now docked. We made it - No Thanks to British Airways - to whom we had submitted all our documentation. And - to be clear about all this: We are requesting Nothing for the Ten hours we futilely stood in line, for the stress and aggravation, for the no sleep, no food at the Heathrow airport. ]I think it is shameful that British Airways would subject their customers to such treatment - then, simply dismiss a polite request for reimbursement.
Unselected: I think it is shameful that British Airways would subject their customers to such treatment - then, simply dismiss a polite request for reimbursement.
Selected: British Airways has refused to reimburse us (wife and I) for expenses we incurred due to their cancellation of our flight. They offered $150 travel voucher each. Our costs are $470.44. We arrived at LHR at 10AM on May 24, 2013. BA advised that all flights were now canceled until 4PM. That meant our 3PM flight to CPH was canceled. We stood in line at BA Customer Service for ten hours, along with hundreds of others. Customer Service only opened 4 windows. As the hours crawled by - tempers flared. We got to the window at 8PM. No flights available this day, nor the next day - that would get us to CPH in time for the evening sailing of our cruise ship. We agreed to an 10AM standby for CPH, and a alternative code share routing that would get us close to the port where the ship would be on the second sailing day. We spent the night wandering Heathrow Airport, and retrieved our checked luggage. Not much sleep. Next morning - no luck at Standby. Rushed to the alternate plan - and flew up to Manchester UK. Then - rushed to another terminal to partner Lufthanza for a flight to Munich Germany. From there, Lufthanza toHamburg - where we arrived at midnight of May 25 - on a weekend night - without a hotel reservation. Taxied to a hotel (very lucky) and got a few hours sleep. May 26 - off to the train station: took train to Rostock, them S-bahn to Warnemunde. Hurray - that is where our cruise ship was now docked. We made it - No Thanks to British Airways - to whom we had submitted all our documentation. And - to be clear about all this: We are requesting Nothing for the Ten hours we futilely stood in line, for the stress and aggravation, for the no sleep, no food at the Heathrow airport.

MergedSelections: [Back in October I purchased a R/T ticket on KLM web for a trip in March 2014 to Entebbe, Uganda. Since October I've routinely checked my itinerary online and up until yesterday everything was in order. Yesterday ]I checked and noticed that my Econ Comfort seats for the JFK-AMS and AMS-EBB legs were missing. I've contact KLM via email; they say their records only show the purchase for the two returning legs. I emailed them a copy of my receipt showing the purchase of all 4 seats and am waiting to hear back from them. My question is: does this happen often? [I looked at the seat map and the flights appear to be very full. I'm concerned that if my seats have been re-sold or given away, I will be out of luck. It's not about getting a refund if that happens, I really want those seats. 24 hours of flying is tough but the KLM Economy Comfort product makes the trip much more pleasant.]

MergedSelections: My daughter and her boyfriend had a delay last year when flying home from Majorca. [We followed all the guidelines and wrote requesting compensation for the 4 hour delay. Thomsons declined stating it was extra ordinary circumstances. Basically the flight from Majorca was delayed because the flight into majorca was delayed due to ongoing planned roundworks near to the airport causing "some staff and passengers to be late for the outgoing flight". These roadworks had been ongoing for more than 2 weeks prior to the date and therefore all staff/passengers should have been aware of the possibilities of delays and allowed extra time. The flight was also n a Sunday evening so this should have not been as much of a problem as it would have been at peak traffic times. After they declined my daughter wrote to the Spanish aviation authority and they agreed and advised compensation should be paid to the amount of é400 per passenger. Thomsons still refused and have refused to answer any further communication. She did all the communication via the online form - should we send in one last letter by post or should we proceed to the small claims court and in our opinions do you think she has a good chance of succeeding with the compensation claim.]
Unselected: My daughter and her boyfriend had a delay last year when flying home from Majorca.
Selected: We followed all the guidelines and wrote requesting compensation for the 4 hour delay. Thomsons declined stating it was extra ordinary circumstances. Basically the flight from Majorca was delayed because the flight into majorca was delayed due to ongoing planned roundworks near to the airport causing "some staff and passengers to be late for the outgoing flight". These roadworks had been ongoing for more than 2 weeks prior to the date and therefore all staff/passengers should have been aware of the possibilities of delays and allowed extra time. The flight was also n a Sunday evening so this should have not been as much of a problem as it would have been at peak traffic times. After they declined my daughter wrote to the Spanish aviation authority and they agreed and advised compensation should be paid to the amount of é400 per passenger. Thomsons still refused and have refused to answer any further communication. She did all the communication via the online form - should we send in one last letter by post or should we proceed to the small claims court and in our opinions do you think she has a good chance of succeeding with the compensation claim.

MergedSelections: My daughter recently booked a flight from London Heathrow to Ottawa via Washington. [On arrival at the airport she was told she needed an Esta form before she could book in. As she was only in transit at Washington airport and not leaving the terminal she was not aware she needed one. Please be aware that you will not be allowed to travel without one. She did eventually obtain an Esta number from the internet site and just managed to catch he flight but it was very stressful and time consuming. She had a connecting flight from Washington to Ottawa with a two hour time span. Please be aware this is not enough time to negotiate customs and immigration and get to your next boarding gate if you are travelling through Dulles airport. Luckily the Wasington to Ottawa flight was delayed or she would have had to spend the night in the airport. They also lost her luggage!!! ]Moral of this story is pay the extra for a direct flight!
Unselected: My daughter recently booked a flight from London Heathrow to Ottawa via Washington. Moral of this story is pay the extra for a direct flight!
Selected: On arrival at the airport she was told she needed an Esta form before she could book in. As she was only in transit at Washington airport and not leaving the terminal she was not aware she needed one. Please be aware that you will not be allowed to travel without one. She did eventually obtain an Esta number from the internet site and just managed to catch he flight but it was very stressful and time consuming. She had a connecting flight from Washington to Ottawa with a two hour time span. Please be aware this is not enough time to negotiate customs and immigration and get to your next boarding gate if you are travelling through Dulles airport. Luckily the Wasington to Ottawa flight was delayed or she would have had to spend the night in the airport. They also lost her luggage!!!

MergedSelections: [Hi there I booked a holiday through Thomascook.com for my wife and I to fly to Kenya in October. This was scheduled to be flying with Monarch Airlines. ]When I received my confirmation - I noticed I was charged £20.00 per person for an extra 5kg of baggage - taking my total UP TO 20kg!!! Is that all?????[ Having looked at the Monarch Airlines website - all passengers flying to Mombasa are allowed a baggage allowance of 35kg PER PASSENGER. If you booked Premium Class this went up to 45kg PER PASSENGER!! I've been in touch with them and they refuse to budge! I've since cancelled my holiday with them and booked through Cosmos and got exactly the deal I was after..... 3 weeks in Kenya to look forward to, and 45kg of luggage each. This will enable us to take extra clothing to distribute among the local population as we did in 2005. Dave Hill]
Unselected: When I received my confirmation - I noticed I was charged £20.00 per person for an extra 5kg of baggage - taking my total UP TO 20kg!!! Is that all?????
Selected: Hi there I booked a holiday through Thomascook.com for my wife and I to fly to Kenya in October. This was scheduled to be flying with Monarch Airlines.  Having looked at the Monarch Airlines website - all passengers flying to Mombasa are allowed a baggage allowance of 35kg PER PASSENGER. If you booked Premium Class this went up to 45kg PER PASSENGER!! I've been in touch with them and they refuse to budge! I've since cancelled my holiday with them and booked through Cosmos and got exactly the deal I was after..... 3 weeks in Kenya to look forward to, and 45kg of luggage each. This will enable us to take extra clothing to distribute among the local population as we did in 2005. Dave Hill

MergedSelections: [I recently flew with Thomson and would never do so again. I flew with one checked bag at a meagre 20kg, and my usual hand luggage bag on wheels. All was perfectly fine on the way OUT (hand luggage was given a cursory glance and declared to be fine), but coming home was a different story. The officials at Crete weighed my hand luggage and found it to be overweight. I had NEVER had hand luggage weighed before, even on the Thomson flight out. I was sent to a different desk in order to check in my hand luggage as a second bag for the hold. I was told this would be €25 and begrudgingly agreed to this, pointing out that this had NOT been a problem on the way over for the SAME bag. Upon reaching the desk, I was told that ON TOP of the €25 I had to pay an amount per every kilo this bag weighed. I was presented with a total fee for checking in a very small hand-luggage sized bag, of....wait for it....€133! The staff were rude, dismissive and told me this was Thompson policy and the airline was rigorous in its baggage checks. This obviously only applies on your return flight, where you have no other option of leaving stuff, and struggle to understand the language and make yourself understood. I felt bullied and was reduced to tears. During discussion, I was told my flight was completely full - it was not. I was also told if I didn't pay up, the €133 would be taken from the pocket of the lady working on the Thomson desk! (really?!) There were other people queuing, all bitterly upset with the surcharges dumped on them for the return flight only. I eventually rectified the situation by donating my beach towels and books to Thomson, and wearing approx 4kg of my clothes, thus saving myself €133. ]Hideous end to a lovely week, all faith in Thomson GONE.[ PS credit to the amazing cabin crew staff who looked after me on the return flight - i could have hugged you all for your kindness.]
Unselected: Hideous end to a lovely week, all faith in Thomson GONE.
Selected: I recently flew with Thomson and would never do so again. I flew with one checked bag at a meagre 20kg, and my usual hand luggage bag on wheels. All was perfectly fine on the way OUT (hand luggage was given a cursory glance and declared to be fine), but coming home was a different story. The officials at Crete weighed my hand luggage and found it to be overweight. I had NEVER had hand luggage weighed before, even on the Thomson flight out. I was sent to a different desk in order to check in my hand luggage as a second bag for the hold. I was told this would be €25 and begrudgingly agreed to this, pointing out that this had NOT been a problem on the way over for the SAME bag. Upon reaching the desk, I was told that ON TOP of the €25 I had to pay an amount per every kilo this bag weighed. I was presented with a total fee for checking in a very small hand-luggage sized bag, of....wait for it....€133! The staff were rude, dismissive and told me this was Thompson policy and the airline was rigorous in its baggage checks. This obviously only applies on your return flight, where you have no other option of leaving stuff, and struggle to understand the language and make yourself understood. I felt bullied and was reduced to tears. During discussion, I was told my flight was completely full - it was not. I was also told if I didn't pay up, the €133 would be taken from the pocket of the lady working on the Thomson desk! (really?!) There were other people queuing, all bitterly upset with the surcharges dumped on them for the return flight only. I eventually rectified the situation by donating my beach towels and books to Thomson, and wearing approx 4kg of my clothes, thus saving myself €133.  PS credit to the amazing cabin crew staff who looked after me on the return flight - i could have hugged you all for your kindness.

MergedSelections: Hold on to your hand luggage if you are travelling to South Africa on British Airways. [Any domestic travel included in your ticket will probably be on South African airline Comair, operating under the British Airways banner. BA/Comair has a “policy” (it happened on both of my flights) of selecting passengers at random and asking them to leave their hand luggage at the door when boarding, as “the cabin is full”. Don’t do it. I did, and had a phone stolen from my bag. When the crew approached me at the door, I asked them if they would stow the bag on board, meaning in the cabin. They said they would. Instead, I ended up collecting my unlocked bag of valuables (minus one) from the carousel in the terminal. To add insult to injury, my bag was well within the regulation size, it fitted comfortably into the overhead locker (on the return trip) and it was all unnecessary as there was plenty of room in the lockers anyway. When I complained to BA at the airport I was told I should not have left valuables in my checked-in luggage! Had I not been so sleep deprived after a long international flight I might have been more circumspect when ambushed by the crew. BA/Comair has not responded to any of the three emails I have sent them. So much for me being accommodating.]
Unselected: Hold on to your hand luggage if you are travelling to South Africa on British Airways.

MergedSelections: Since Usairways merger with American our service and prices have suffered out of Charlotte.[ My last experience made me vow to never fly them unless I absolutely had to. My wife and I just returned from a round trip via Delta from Charlotte to Jacksonville, FL. We flew first class cheaper than a coach seat on AA. From the moment we stepped up to the ticket counter in Charlotte until we got our baggage back at the end of the trip, it was amazing to experience the difference in service. The comparison between first class on Delta and first class on AA is amazing. Delta on each leg had chilled water bottles waiting at our seat, fresh blankets, pillows, and the flight attendants came down the aisle and took drink orders on the ground, and seamlessly replaced empty water bottles. Snacks were first rate and included fresh fruit and unique offerings. The entire crew was dressed very sharply, smiled, and actually thanked us for flying with them. They seemed to genuinely enjoy their jobs. Every flight on AA that we've taken since the merger we could hear the flight attendants complaining and they could care less about the service. Not once did passengers get berated by the flight attendants to hurry up so they could have an on time departure by the Delta crews....it is common place on AA. It was as if we stepped back in time when air travel was enjoyable. On each leg of the trip, our luggage was waiting on us when we arrived at baggage claim. AA is lucky to get it to you within 30 minutes.] Best decision we've made to switch our business to Delta.
Unselected: Since Usairways merger with American our service and prices have suffered out of Charlotte. Best decision we've made to switch our business to Delta.
Selected: My last experience made me vow to never fly them unless I absolutely had to. My wife and I just returned from a round trip via Delta from Charlotte to Jacksonville, FL. We flew first class cheaper than a coach seat on AA. From the moment we stepped up to the ticket counter in Charlotte until we got our baggage back at the end of the trip, it was amazing to experience the difference in service. The comparison between first class on Delta and first class on AA is amazing. Delta on each leg had chilled water bottles waiting at our seat, fresh blankets, pillows, and the flight attendants came down the aisle and took drink orders on the ground, and seamlessly replaced empty water bottles. Snacks were first rate and included fresh fruit and unique offerings. The entire crew was dressed very sharply, smiled, and actually thanked us for flying with them. They seemed to genuinely enjoy their jobs. Every flight on AA that we've taken since the merger we could hear the flight attendants complaining and they could care less about the service. Not once did passengers get berated by the flight attendants to hurry up so they could have an on time departure by the Delta crews....it is common place on AA. It was as if we stepped back in time when air travel was enjoyable. On each leg of the trip, our luggage was waiting on us when we arrived at baggage claim. AA is lucky to get it to you within 30 minutes.
